text: this is how many Iranian women dress
when they go out and this is what the
country's Islamic government wants them
to wear a headscarf
which hides all they hair and a long
loose coat women who don't comply fully
with the government's dress code risk
arrest fines or lashes this footage was
filmed inside Iran and has been widely
shared in social media
it cannot be independently verified it
appears to show a woman being arrested
by Iranian polls because of the world
she's dressed the hijab is an
inseparable part of ideology of the
Islamic Republic of Iran but life was
very different in Iran before the
Revolution people dressed in Iran on
those days as they do in any
multicultural society some people were
dressed like I'm dressed now some would
come out with her job if he went to the
mosque for example we used to wear job
but if you were at the seaside we were
dressed in swimsuits or bikinis but
after the Islamic Republic of Iran was
established in 1979 life for women in
Iran changed dramatically 11th of April
I went to hospital and gave birth to my
daughter and the next day when I wanted
to come out my mother brought a scarf
and said you can't go without the hijab
in the street it's very dangerous they
will throw acids on you so it that's how
it became compulsory
35 years on and Iran has a new young
generation with increasing exposure to
Western fashions more and more women
resist government restrictions on their
heater but only a few dare to go without
it those who do have to hide their
identity I don't believe in the hijab I
don't see any reason why I should cover
myself and I don't believe in it so I go
out dressed as a man a risk a lot of
danger by doing it but then I fell on
free many young Iranians now have access
to the Internet and satellite TV
channels the clothes they choose to wear
are becoming a challenge to the
authorities
Miriam Ansari BBC News
